newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-A LITTLE LIE KEEPS CONE IN THE GAME.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-A LITTLE LIE KEEPS CONE IN THE GAME.

text.p: A key moment in the New York Yankees' life-saving World Series victory Tuesday came in the sixth inning, when pitcher David Cone told a little lie that kept him in the game.

Cone was starting to lose it a little bit. He had done the the unthinkable by walking his opposing pitcher, Tom Glavine, to lead off the inning on a 3-2 pitch. He then yielded a single to Marquis Grissom and an out later walked Chipper Jones to load the bases with the dangerous Atlanta Braves slugger Fred McGriff coming to the plate.

Yankee manager Joe Torre walked out to the mound to confer with Cone. "I just wanted him to level with me because I knew he wanted to stay in the game no matter what. And I just needed him to be real truthful and be there, and he was," said Torre.

"I just asked him, I said, 'It's very important here,' I said, 'I've got to know are you OK?' He said, 'I'm fine, I'm just losing the splitter and it's more a mechanical thing than anything else.' He wasn't tired and he felt fine, and I looked in his eyes and I believed him," recalled Torre, who left Cone in the game.
But Cone said there was a little deception involved.
"Joe got as close as he could to me, face to face, and implored me to be honest with him. And I did my best to lie, to tell him I had something left and I'm going to get him through this inning.
"I got us in that jam. There's no worse feeling than coming out with the bases loaded and the next guy comes in and it's a burden on the relief guy.
"That game right there was mine to win or lose."
Cone said the deception was as much directed at himself as at his manager.
"You sort of trick yourself, yeah, I can get Fred McGriff out with the bases loaded, yeah, right."
Cone did get McGriff out on pop-up before walking Ryan Klesko for Atlanta's first run, which made it 2-1. But he got Javier Lopez on a foul pop-out, and the threat was over.
Cone was done, too, yielding the mound to the Yankees' nonpareil set-up man Mariano Rivera in the next inning.
The Yanks were on their way to the 5-2 win that got them back in the Series, although trailing two games to one.
